Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Supporting Pedagogical Innovation for a Generation of Transformation via Inquiry-Based Learning in Mathematics (SPIGOT)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
SPIGOT, Supporting Pedagogical Innovation for a Generation Of Transformation, is providing intensive four-day workshops in Inquiry-Based Learning (IBL) in college mathematics. Led by experienced faculty developers and IBL practitioners, the SPIGOT workshops engage about 120 mathematics instructors from diverse institutions, especially early-career faculty, in one of three summer workshops. Workshops prepare instructors to implement research-based, student-centered approaches to teaching and learning. Conference-based mini-workshops serve as an on-ramp to the intensive workshops.

SPIGOT's design is informed by faculty-development literature and experience to address major obstacles to change. It draws upon existing infrastructure of the Academy of Inquiry-Based Learning to support participants' long-term engagement with an active community of practice. As instructors adopt IBL in one or more courses, thousands of students experience potentially transformative mathematics education.

The evaluation-with-research study is gathering data on faculty response to the workshops and aspects of their local context that help or hinder implementation of an IBL course. Such data offer formative feedback to the workshop leaders and add to knowledge about how best to encourage faculty uptake of these proven methods. Dissemination of the study findings will target both mathematics educators and the broader STEM education community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Supporting Pedagogical Innovation for a Generation of Transformation via Inquiry-Based Learning in Mathematics (SPIGOT) has made a significant impact in the area of mathematics teaching in higher education.  The SPIGOT workshops offered intensive professional development opportunities for college math instructors from 2013 to 2016, providing participants opportunties to learn to teach via inquiry-based learning (IBL).

In total, 138 college math instructors learned how to teach using IBL and developed materials and strategies for specific target courses they would teach in the subsequent academic year. Workshop sessions addressed specific obstacles and challenges facing college math instructors.  These challenges include learning IBL teaching skills, studying how students learn Math, developing appropriate tasks, matching course content to course goals, and using appropriate assessments.

During just the first year after the workshops, the 138 participants taught more than 180 courses using IBL methods to at least 4600 students.  Further, 76% of all participants indicated they were using IBL methods, indicating high uptake rates for our professional development model. More than 60% of participants were classified as early-career faculty, and slightly more than half of our participants are women. 

The SPIGOT team achieved these results by designing a workshop model to precisely address an array of instructor needs and challenges, using a broad and flexible "Big Tent" IBL framework. Key issues and challenges were identified, gathered, and prioritized. Faciltators shared the IBL framework with a range of option with participants. Facilitators worked individually with participants to problem solve their specific teaching challenges, customizing IBL methods to best suit their needs. Further, evaluation data and education research were used in a cycle of inquiry to make improvements to the workshop model after each iteration.

In addition to the impact on the 138 paricipants and their students, SPIGOT developed and enhanced a professional development model that could be used more broadly in higher education, as interest in IBL increases. In particular, our IBL Workshop model could be a component of a broader effort to increase uptake of active learning pedagogies at the college level in STEM disciplines.
